topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack 2.0: Configuring for VSA Block Storage Backend

section.p: This page describes how to configure your VSA backend for the Helion Entry Scale Cloud with KVM model.Discovery functionality of VSA nodes using CMC controller node is not recommended in HP Helion OpenStack 2.0. User needs to manually add VSA and create a cluster.

section.title: Pre-requisites

ul.li: The deployer node must be setup before deploying VSA. For more details on the installation of deployer node, refer here.

You'll need to know the IP address of the VSA VM and VSA Cluster from the ~/scratch/ansible/last/my_cloud/stage/info/net_info.yml file, which is generated by configuration processor during installation.

section.p: You can deploy VSA with adoptive optimization (AO) or without. The process to deploy VSA with AO and without AO is similar with the exception of a change in the disk input model. For more detailed information, refer to the VSA with AO and without AO section below.

section.title: Creating a StoreVirtual Cluster and adding it to a new Management Group Cluster using CMC
section.p: The CMC utility requires a GUI to access it. These steps below will allow you to setup a VNC connect to your controller node so you can view the GUI.

ol.li: Login to your first controller node.
Run the following command to install some packages necessary to launch CMC: sudo apt-get install -y xrdp xterm xbase-clients xfonts-base vnc4server

Start vnc4server using the instructions below. You will be prompted for a password (min 6 characters). Enter a password and proceed. The output will look like this: stack@helion-cp1-c1-m1-mgmt:~$ vnc4server
You will require a password to access your desktops.
Password: Verify: xauth: file /home/stack/.Xauthority does not exist
New 'helion-cp1-c1-m1-mgmt:3 (stack)' desktop is helion-cp1-c1-m1-mgmt:3
Creating default startup script /home/stack/.vnc/xstartup Starting applications specified in /home/stack/.vnc/xstartup Log file is /home/stack/.vnc/helion-cp1-c1-m1-mgmt:3.log

Run netstat -anp | grep vnc to determine the public port. In the example below it is port 5903: stack@helion-cp1-c1-m1-mgmt:~$ netstat -anp | grep vnc (Not all processes could be identified, non-owned process info will not be shown, you would have to be root to see it all.) tcp 0 0 0.0.0.0:6003 0.0.0.0:* LISTEN 1413/Xvnc4 tcp6 0 0 :::5903 :::* LISTEN 1413/Xvnc4
You should then be able to connect to your controller node via any remote desktop or VNC client using the IP address, port, and password to access the CMC GUI diplay.

section.p:
Perform the following steps to create the cluster.
Open CMC.
By default, the CMC is configured to discover the StoreVirtual nodes in the subnet in which it is installed. You can manually add the nodes also.
In the CMC UI, click Find and then click Find Systems from the left panel. Find Systems dialogue box is displayed.
You can choose Add or Find option to search the system. Find option starts searching for the nodes in the same subnet as that of CMC. Add option displays an Enter IP pop-up box to enter the IP of the StoreVirtual system.
In the CMC UI, click Tasks then point to Management Group and click New Management Group.
In the New Management Group Name box, enter a name for the management group. For example: hlm003-vsa-mg
Click Next to display the Add Administrative User page.
Enter the required information (username/password) for the Administrative User.
For example:
username- stack
password-stack
Click Next to display the Management Group Time page.
Add NTP server information and click Next to display the Domain Name System Configuration page.
Skip the DNS and SMTP sections. To do so,
Cllick Next and . A pop box displays and click Accept Incomplete.
Click Next to display a Wizard in the Create a Cluster page.
Select the cluster type as Standard Cluster from the displayed options and click Next.
In the Cluster Name box, enter the name of the cluster and click Next. For example: hlm003-vsa-cluster.
In the Assign Virtaula IP's and Subnet Masks page is displayed.
Click Add. Add VIPs and Subnet Masks pop-up box displays, enter the virtual IP and Subnet Mask of the cluster in the respective boxes and click OK. The VIP IP can be found as the cluster IP value in the ~/scratch/ansible/next/my_cloud/stage/info/net_info.yml file.
Click Next to go to the next page.
Select the checkbox displayed against Skip Volume Creation.
Click Finish.The Management Group and Cluster is created and displays in the Home page of CMC.
Wait till the cluster is displayed in the Home Page of CMC.

section.title: Configure VSA as a Cinder Backend
section.p: You must modify cinder.conf.j2 to update VSA cluster.

Perform the following steps to update the VSA cluster:
Login to deployer node.
Edit ~/helion/my_cloud/config/cinder/cinder.conf.j2 to add VSA data as follows: # Configure the enabled backends enabled_backends=vsa-1
Copy VSA section, uncomment it, and modify the values in the cinder.conf.j2 file as shown in the following example: [vsa-1] hplefthand_password: <password given during cluster creation> hplefthand_clustername: <VSA cluster name> hplefthand_api_url: https://<store virtual virtual ip>:8081/lhos hplefthand_username: <username given during cluster creation> hplefthand_iscsi_chap_enabled: true volume_backend_name: <volume backend name> volume_driver: cinder.volume.drivers.san.hp.hp_lefthand_iscsi.HPLeftHandISCSIDriver hplefthand_debug: false
where,
hplefthand_password : Password given during cluster creation.
hplefthand_clustername: Name of the VSA cluster.
hplefthand_api_url: Virtual IP of Store Virtual.
hplefthand_username: Username given during cluster creation.
hplefthand_iscsi_chap_enabled :
volume_backend_name: Name of the backend.
volume_driver
hplefthand_debug HOS 2.0 is expected to support physical lefthand boxes along with VSA deployed on ESX, hyper-v environment Please enter the parameter values which are specific to your environment.
Commit your configuration to a local repository: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "your commit message" Enter your commit message in quotes
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Run the following command to create a deployment directory. cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

body.p: Execute the following command to configure VSA.

You must verify the VSA configuration as backend by creating the volume and volume type. Once you are able to create the volume, you can delete the created volume. For more information, refer to Verify Backend Configuration.
body.note: You can create more than one VSA cluster of same or different type by specifying the configuration in cloud model. For more details, refer Modifying Cloud Model to Create Multiple Clusters.

section.title: VSA with AO and without AO
section.p: VSA is deployed with adoptive optimization (AO) and without AO. AO allows built-in storage tiering for VSA. While deploying VSA with or without AO you must ensure to use the appropriate disk input model.

VSA with AO will have extra disk section with the marked usage of adoptive-optimization as mentioned in the following example: Additional disks can be added if available device_groups: - name: vsa-data consumer: name: vsa usage: data devices: - name: /dev/sdc - name: /dev/sdd - name: /dev/sde - name: /dev/sdf
- name: vsa-cache consumer: name: vsa usage: adaptive-optimization devices: - name: /dev/sdb

VSA without AO consist of data disks as mentioned in the following example: Additional disks can be added if available device_groups: - name: vsa-data consumer: name: vsa usage: data devices: - name: /dev/sdc - name: /dev/sdd - name: /dev/sde - name: /dev/sdf
It is recommended to use SSD disk for AO. The minimum VSA deployment with AO is 2 (apart from OS disk) and 1 for VSA without AO. However, the maximum supported disk is 7.
